posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14570226
Do you know what that actually is in your pic? It's not human remains encased in lava if that's what you're thinking. The city of Pompeii was buried by a cloud of superheated ash that killed everyone, then buried their bodies. When excavating the city, archaeologists would discover human shaped voids in the rock. That was where a person died and had their body surrounded by the ash. Eventually the body decomposed completely, but the void in the rock where it once was remained. So they poured plaster into the void and then cut away the rock around it, revealing the things in your pic. It was essentially a mold to make a statue of a man's last moments, but those figures are not the remains of the man.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The people of Pompeii died primarily due to the intense heat and ash produced by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD. The ash and pumice that erupted from the volcano buried the city, preserving it for nearly 1700 years. It is unlikely that many people would have been able to outrun the lava, as it was flowing at high speeds and the ash cloud produced by the eruption would have made it difficult to see and breathe. Additionally, the residents of Pompeii would not have had any prior experience with a volcanic eruption of this scale, and would not have fully understood the danger they were facing.

>anon, my whole point was that there is a difference between sex and gender. what intersex people are assigned at birth is an example of this.
That's fine, as long as you're not denying sex as a meaningful but imperfect form of categorization that exists based on real differences between groups of people.
>Intersex means between the sexes.
49 may be closer to 1 than 100, but it is still between 1 and 100.
Honestly, the precise way you classify it is just arguing over words. Point is that there are differences used to divide them into "male or female" regardless of their condition.

For example, read here
https://medlineplus.gov/genetics/condition/persistent-mullerian-duct-syndrome/
>Persistent Müllerian duct syndrome is a disorder of sexual development that affects males. Males with this disorder have normal male reproductive organs, though they also have a uterus and fallopian tubes, which are female reproductive organs. The uterus and fallopian tubes are derived from a structure called the Müllerian duct during development of the fetus. The Müllerian duct usually breaks down during early development in males, but it is retained in those with persistent Müllerian duct syndrome. Affected individuals have the normal chromosomes of a male (46,XY) and normal external male genitalia.
This is an example of what I'm saying, it's called a condition that "affects males." That's traditionally how people spoke about intersex conditions, maybe it's changing now. Regardless of the language though, there are real differences based on what happens at different stages of the typical male and female paths of development. It's not arbitrary calling them male or female.
>They may lean one way or another, but in most cases excluding Turner syndrome, they are objectively not male or female in the conventional sex
There's many intersex conditions like that where only males or females are affected. Klinefelter syndrome only affects males for example.

>>14568659
>I can easily imagine how I wake up tomorrow in a different body, it can be the body of a girl, or even a sexless robot.

But it doesn't tough. If it did, then yes, you would have became a girl or a robot.

>when I am in the cabin of a helicopter, I do not become identical to this helicopter

True, but that's because it is possible to get into and out of a helicopter very easily. You just walk in and out and that's it. If it became that easy to switch sexes, then we probably would start to view the body as separate from the essense as a helicopter.

But since sex is today a permanent feature of a person (it is possible to change some sexual traits through medical procedure, but they are long, hard and irreversable), it makes sense people view it almost as part of the essense.

You can se the same logic in language in many cases in reference to the body. We say "I have long hair" instead of "I am lon-haired" because getting a haircut and growing it out again is relatively easy. But we say "I am short" instead of "I have a short body" because height is unchangable, or even "I am fat" instead of "I have fat" because losing weight takes a long time. So if in a far future changing your physical sex becomes as trivial as getting a haircut, we would start to use similar language like for hair, and see sex as separate fromw the essense of a person.

posts.com:
I'm not asking for "objective" analyses on whether the world is getting better or worse.

What I'm interested in is the current trend where there seems to be a concerted effort in newspapers, magazines, television and social media to convince people the world is getting better. Or more specifically, the perceived need to perform such convincing.
Is this a new phenomenon in recent times? I'm talking of the world in say 1950-2000, not the fall of Rome, or times of war, or the dawn of the industrial revolution.
When I look at archive footage, old interviews of both experts and laymen on the street, newspaper clippings, or just think back to life in the 20th century, I don't see this nearly as strongly. People have always had differences of opinion, some more positive than others, but I can't notice a similar urge at times on the verge of desperation to try to convince the people that things are in fact progressing in a positive direction.
Am I just imagining things, is the perception of the past skewed by what has been archived etc. or has this sort of borderline propagandistic "upselling" of our situation and/or the felt need by authorities to take part in such convincing really had a noticable uptick in recent decades?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What I meant by "upselling", and maybe it was an awkward expression, is that a lot of the times this sort of convincing is used in the context of trying to get people more invested in society. Countering those who are fatalistically proclaiming that no matter what people do they lack the capacity to stop the world from degenerating. Citing statistics or something else argue that we are in fact headed for collapse.

This type of "it's really not as bad as you think" messaging seems to aim to draw more people in to established institutions whether it's college, the 9-to-5, making investments, or tying your future more closely to that of the society at large in some other way. Demanding a larger contribution or reliance from you, but arguing that it'll work out in the end, as the direction this "machine" is headed is actually a positive one and you get to be a part of it.

Youtube is full of old street interviews from the 60s, 70s and 80s, and maybe the sample size is skewed toward people having already been convinced since they're in the big city, but people in general just seem "excited for new opportunities". There does not seem to be a need to try and convince people that these opportunities are something they want. A more "build it and they will come" type approach, where the advantages are self-evident and people will naturally flock to them, whereas in our times larger parts of the population must have begun to look at such institutions more critically and need more convincing that they really do want what is offered. Or at the very least the people in power seem to be afraid that is the case, as it's hard to even open a newspaper these days without at least opinion peace or columnist writing about how the world is ACTUALLY headed in a good direction DESPITE what you may think.

During the last months of his administration, an infuriated John Adams went around frantically appointing Federalist justices to stymie Thomas Jefferson. This included Chief Justice John Marshall, who lasted into the Jackson Administration and out-lived his own party as he continued to hand down Federalist decisions for over three decades.

Particularly irritating was Associate Justice Samuel Chase, who was so despised by Democratic-Republicans that they named wild dogs after him. Jefferson tried to have the temperamental, coarse-tongued Chase impeached and removed from the Supreme Court. However, Congress, during the impeachment proceedings, failed to find any evidence that he'd committed high crimes and misdemeanors, or was guilty of anything more than a loose tongue and conduct unbecoming of a Supreme Court justice. The impeachment attempt failed and Chase remained on the court until his death in 1811.

This was the first and last attempt to impeach a Supreme Court justice and its failure went aways to establishing the judiciary's independence.

What exactly is your problem with income taxes? It's not like there were no federal taxes before the 16th amendment. Congress just had to apportion them to the states based on population instead of to individuals based on income, which is a much fairer and more efficient system.

After the 16th amendment when income taxes were created, that unfairness was done away with. Yet people complain about it.

>>14570283
Pretty much. That's been the argument for centuries. A strong central government is a tradeoff, and as against it as I am I will admit that the upside is being able to create a strong, coordinated national response in times of crisis.

I believe that the harms of a strong central government tend to outweigh the benefits. The characteristics that make a government ill equipped to tackle large-scale problems like climate change, pandemic or foreign invasion, are the ones that shield the people against government misuse of that power--say, involvement in unnecessary foreign wars (cough, cough, Vietnam), gross infringements of individual liberties nationwide (assault weapon bans, the War on Drugs, the NSA and illegal surveillance just to name a few) and gross misallocation of tax revenue motivated by short-term political strategy rather than the long-term interest of the nation (agricultural and energy subsidies come to mind). The real-world harm that has been done to us by those things--and it is a lot of harm, just because it has been normalized in the public opinion today doesn't make it okay--is not worth the benefit.

The other problem with a strong national government is that it causes everyone to think nationally on all issues. The whole fucking point of having states is an acknowledgement that people living in different regions in the US want to be governed differently. No one in California wants to live under the same rules that they want in Kentucky, for cultural as well as material reasons. But with a strong national government--especially since the Civil War--activists on all issues skip straight to the federal level on issues that really ought to be handled by the state. Abortion, marijuana, all kinds of shit really should be handled at the state level but instead you have California liberals and Kentucky conservatives fighting over having one policy on the issue for the entire nation. No wonder the partisanship is so bitter.

The problem is that it's too easy to dodge. Everyone knows that the rich all hide their income in offshore banks while the burden gets put on the middle class. Even the federalists acknowledged this. Federalist Papers No. 12:

>...personal property is too precarious and invisible a fund to be laid hold of in any other way than by the inperceptible agency of taxes on consumption.

The whole explanation is way longer but too wordy to post here. The most appropriate ways for a state to tax are on the consumption of goods, because you can't dodge or cheat your way out of that as easily as you can with income, and on property. For income you can take your income as stocks or some other instruments and use all kinds of loopholes and writeoffs to make it not appear as "income" in a traditional sense, it's way simpler to say that any time anyone pays anyone else for a good or a service, the government takes a (tiny) percent of that transaction. And for property, I believe that the government is justified in taxing property because it's a finite resource that's inherently part of the nation. Your real estate isn't "yours" the same way your car or your microwave or your toothbrush is, because no matter what you want it's still a part of the geographic area that is America. You don't have sovereignty over your own property, I think that gives a right to tax it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14571052
In January 1994, Yang and Filo were electrical engineering graduate students at Stanford University, when they created a website named "Jerry and David's guide to the World Wide Web". The site was a human-edited web directory, organized in a hierarchy, as opposed to a searchable index of pages. In March 1994, "Jerry and David's Guide to the World Wide Web" was renamed "Yahoo!" and became known as the Yahoo Directory. The "yahoo.com" domain was registered on January 18, 1995. The word "yahoo" is a backronym for "Yet Another Hierarchically Organized Oracle" or "Yet Another Hierarchical Officious Oracle". The term "hierarchical" described how the Yahoo database was arranged in layers of subcategories. The term "oracle" was intended to mean "source of truth and wisdom", and the term "officious", rather than being related to the word's normal meaning, described the many office workers who would use the Yahoo database while surfing from work. However, Filo and Yang insist they mainly selected the name because they liked the slang definition of a "yahoo" (used by college students in David Filo's native Louisiana in the late 1980s and early 1990s to refer to an unsophisticated, rural Southerner): "rude, unsophisticated, uncouth." This meaning derives from the Yahoo race of fictional beings from Gulliver's Travels. Yahoo was incorporated on March 2, 1995. In 1995, a search engine function, called Yahoo Search, was introduced. This allowed users to search Yahoo Directory. Yahoo soon became the first popular online directory and search engine on the World Wide Web.

Not only the provisions but the ammunition is all gone.
Thirty-two men hear the news and hurry to the scene.
The heavy strokes of their sabers lead them into the fortress, through the ranks of the enemy to see
The commander of the fortress wet with blood,
And his men reeling against the walls with exhaustion but with swords in hand.
Now comes the dauntless South Carolinian,
Knowing that if he does not answer duty's call, disgrace and shame will be his.
Returning he rides into the siege on a white charger,
Salutes the besieged with a smile, and says, "We die together."
They bind up their wounds and fight in higher spirits.
Speak not of the bravery of Chang Hsun at Suiyang, for here the one hundred and eighty-two corpses were laid; not one surrendered.
The people of the twenty-four states get inspiration thereby,
And learn for the first time that unanimous cooperation is superior to geographical advantage.
Why should they be mourned? For the dauntless, it is not a pain but a pleasure to cover an obstruction miles long.
Lo! the mouth of the river once occupied by the enemy is in the possession of the T' ang!
Now I am on a journey, far away from my home across the ocean.
I have come to San Antonio, where there are bushes of the graceful oleander.
And, as in a dream, I wonder if this is the very spot where that dreadful bloodshed took place in years gone by.
You do not see Chang Hsun, Hsu Yuan, and Nan Chiyun (David Crockett, Bowie, and Bonham)
But their fame, like the blossom's fragrance, is still in the air.
The custom of the West does not necessarily condemn surrender.
Why? We have never heard of a commander destroyed,
But here in the state of Texas, we see one (Travis).
In spirit there is not a distinction between East and West.
You need not wonder, then, if I drink a toast to your memory!
I have brought a well-polished stone from Japan,
And commemorate your heroic deeds with this humble inscription.

The concept of God's virginity is not a universally held belief across all religions and spiritual traditions. Some religious texts and teachings depict God or a divine being as beyond the constraints of human biology and gender, while others depict God as having masculine or feminine qualities.

In Christianity, for example, there is no explicit teaching about God's virginity, and the concept is not central to the faith. Some Christian mystics and theologians have drawn on the image of the "eternal virgin" to describe the purity and transcendence of God, but this is not a universally held belief within Christianity.

In other religious traditions, such as Hinduism or some forms of esoteric Buddhism, the concept of a divine being being a virgin or beyond the constraints of human biology and gender may be present.

In general, beliefs about the nature of God and divine beings are shaped by the religious and cultural context in which they arise, and can vary widely depending on the tradition and interpretation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are no "laws of history" in the same sense that there are laws of physics or mathematics. History is a complex and multi-faceted subject that is shaped by a wide range of factors, including cultural, political, economic, and social developments, technological innovations, and individual and collective human actions.

While there are patterns and trends that can be observed in history, these patterns are not predictable with the same certainty as natural laws. Furthermore, the study of history is often subjective and can be influenced by the perspectives and biases of those who study and interpret it.

However, some scholars have attempted to formulate general principles that describe the nature of historical change, including ideas about the cyclical nature of history, the role of geography and demography in shaping historical events, and the idea of historical determinism, which posits that certain events are predetermined and that history is moving inevitably in a particular direction.

It is important to recognize that these ideas are just that - ideas - and that there is no one universally accepted set of laws that govern the course of human history. The study of history remains a dynamic and ever-evolving field, with new perspectives and approaches constantly emerging as our understanding of the past evolves.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14566261
>A Von Neumann probe shouldn't be out of reach even with our limited technology
I think one thing people will increasingly realise over the next 100 or so years is that computers don't last long at all. Bits can flip due to charged particles, which will ruin even a self-replicating self correcting program very quickly when travelling through unprotrcted space. Not to mention that the actual chemical composition of the computer will be changed by ionising radiation over time, which on the small scale of a processor matters a lot. I think it's one of the primary reasons why whenever NASA sends a probe to Mars, a number of the instruments are usually broken on arrival even though they are built and rated to survive the trip.
An interstellar trip is probably not possible with a computer sufficient to rebuild the spacecraft it's on.

posts.com:
The fall of the Roman Empire was a complex and multi-faceted event that was influenced by a variety of factors, and the conversion of the empire to Christianity is just one of many factors that contributed to its decline.

Some historians have argued that the conversion of the empire to Christianity weakened it in several ways. For example, the conversion led to the establishment of a powerful and centralized Church that became a rival to the state and sometimes challenged the authority of the emperor. In addition, the spread of Christianity led to the fragmentation of Roman society, as different sects and factions within the Church competed for power and influence.

However, other historians argue that the conversion of the Roman Empire to Christianity was not a major factor in its decline, and that there were many other, more significant causes of the empire's collapse. These include economic factors, such as a declining economy and overreliance on slavery, political factors, such as military overstretch and the inability to manage a vast and diverse empire, and social factors, such as declining birth rates and the spread of disease.

In general, the fall of the Roman Empire was the result of a complex interplay of factors, and it is difficult to attribute its decline to a single cause or factor, including the conversion to Christianity.

The idea of immortality and the supernatural has been a part of human culture and belief systems for thousands of years, but actually pursuing it in a systematic and scientific way is a relatively recent development. Throughout history, the pursuit of immortality has often been tied to religious or spiritual beliefs and practices, rather than a purely scientific or rational approach.

Additionally, the idea of immortality or supernatural powers has often been shrouded in mystery and superstition, making it difficult for people to approach it in a systematic and scientific way. In some cultures, the pursuit of immortality or supernatural powers was seen as taboo or even dangerous, leading many people to shy away from it.

As for the few historical figures you mentioned, such as the Count of St. Germain or Rasputin, their pursuit of immortality or supernatural powers was often shrouded in secrecy and may have been influenced by personal motivations and beliefs that are not widely known or understood.

In general, it is important to be cautious about making sweeping generalizations about people based on limited or one-dimensional information, and to try to understand individuals and their beliefs and actions in a nuanced and multi-faceted manner.

posts.com:
...Nixon's arrival on the stage of national politics happened with his 1946 election to Congress. The 12th Congressional district of California was then held by Democrat Jerry Voorhis, a convinced New Dealer who'd rode into office a decade earlier on the coattails of FDR's landslide 1936 reelection. The son of the Nash Motors president, Voorhis was a dilettante and not much of a hands-on politician--he hated wheeling and dealing and the more dirty side of politics. An avid writer and thinker, he authored three long-forgotten books on monetary reform, one of his pet subjects, and he eagerly supported all vaguely left-of-center causes. Skilled at marketing himself to whatever constituents he was addressing, he could don a straw hat and sandals and smoke a pipe as he sat down on a street corner to chat with Mexican farm workers, and the next day wear a suit and tie as he spoke to a businessman's club.

Despite having a rather negligible voting record and being a vague, long-winded speaker who seldom got a clear point across, Voorhis was easily reelected four times against tomato can Republican opponents and had no idea how to face an actual challenger. By 1946, the times were changing and California voters wanted to put the New Deal behind them. Shortages, rationing, and top-down government management had outstayed their welcome, and the five term Congressman might be vulnerable. On the surface it would not seem so however, as Voorhis enjoyed incumbent's advantage, and the largest constituency in his district was blue collar workers and farm laborers, both solid Democrat voting blocs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Voorhis had the practice of monitoring birth notices in the local papers and sending congratulations letters and a government-provided baby care book to new parents in his district, a common practice for Congressmen in this era. This worked to Nixon's advantage when him and Pat welcomed their daughter Tricia into the world on February 21, 1946--Pat had toiled long hours in the latter stages of her pregnancy mimeographing and sending out letters and campaign literature for her husband's Congressional campaign. Nixon issued a statement reading "She is the only boss I will recognize. Patricia is a lucky girl. She will grow up in the finest state in the union in the greatest country on Earth, and when the time comes she will register and vote Republican."

Nixon's campaign message was straightforward and spoke to the large body of young military veterans in the 12th district who wanted a "return to normalcy" and an end to government micromanagement of the economy. He also charged Voorhis with being an unabashed leftist and communist, and an ally of the "infamous" Congressmen Helen Douglas and Vito Marcantonio, "whose views are well-known to everyone." Speaking to the Kiwani Club in March, Nixon discussed the danger the USSR posed to the free world. He went into a long expose of Russian history, which he said was "a tragic story of war, starvation, torture, rape, murder, and slavery. They have never in all their history known as we Americans have the peaceful existence of neighboring states with established boundaries. To them all foreigners are potential enemies. They have never known any leaders but dictators."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
He then overviewed Russian history and its numerous despotic rulers since the Middle Ages, and down to the modern day of Soviet communism. "Russia has now grabbed Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Eastern Poland, part of Finland, Czechoslovakia, and Romania. The Soviets do not need these parts of Europe now that the Soviet government is strong and firmly entrenched, but it is weak in the light of history because it has set itself against the surge of mankind towards freedom and democracy."

A poor showing by Voorhis in the electoral primary in June, just 53% of the vote, showed that he was clearly no longer a shoe-in for reelection. His endorsement by the National Political Action Committee appeared to be red meat to Republicans as the PAC was a symbol of New Deal excesses and widely reviled as a den of unabashed communists and fellow travelers. This was unfair because these people were never the majority of the PAC, and Voorhis himself was relatively moderate in his views and openly disavowed communists.

By late October, most of the newspapers in the 12th district had endorsed Nixon, including the powerful Los Angeles Times. Nixon did not repeat the mistakes of past Republicans who ran against Voorhis, most of whom championed abstract right wing talking points with no real, practical message that would appeal to voters. Nixon for comparison openly talked of the disorder gripping California in the aftermath of V-J Day and its effect on people's daily lives. On November 4, Nixon swept into office with 57% of the vote and almost every polling area in the district, including Voorhis's home town of San Dimas.

In truth this was silly and comes off as "sore loser syndrome"--most of Nixon's supporters and principle donors were middle class voters--college educated professionals and independent small businessmen who rallied to his "get the government off people's backs" message. The biggest single cash influx Nixon received was $12,000 from the RNC after former president Hoover, still widely regarded as the titular head of the Republican Party, was vacationing in California and became impressed enough by hearing Nixon speak that he got on the phone and ordered extra cash diverted to what had been seen at the onset as a hopeless campaign.

Small towns outlived their use the moment farming mechanized and railroads electrified. It was only a matter of time between the steam shovel and total destruction of rural lifestyles, pastoral lifestyles especially. Industrialized society operates on mass production and mass production requires highly concentrated authority, specialized labor, and working capital. Farmers knew this for centuries, it's how Rome fell when Senators created regional monopolies to undercut rural towns, but in the 20th century the rapid advancement of electrical machines and electrical chemistry completely invalidated that type of human society in the same way farming eliminated nomadic herding. Globalization was inevitable and with it consolidation of resources, including human capital, into gigantic metroplexes.

Chicago was the first modern city in this regard, having been rebuilt around railroads in 1871 and being explicitly re-built around electricity after New York successfully demonstrated it. Insull killed all the small towns in the rural midwest as his literal power base enabled gigantic factories that utterly destroyed the small town smithy as the railroads killed the pony express. By the time the government intervened to regulate it, the damage was already done and permanent. The subsequent development of automobiles and the haber-bosch process utterly annihilated anyone who survived. Orson Wells made a drama about it.

I also agree with your statement, but the ball started rolling the moment steam power was harnessed for land-based vehicles. That was the moment social conservatism would have to unravel from economic conservatism. As much was predicted by Adam Smith (who was actually very cautious about capitalist industry), and later expanded on with Marx and Engels.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14568321
>Why are some accents considered superior?
Money. Both class and ethnic-based accents are derided due to their associated status, typically with wealth and power. In Australia, three class accents exist, Broad, mostly spoken by working class suburbanites and rural people (think Steve Irwin), General, mostly spoken by middle class urbanites and suburbanites (think Hugh Jackman); and Cultivated, spoken mostly by those deridedly called the 'bunyip aristocracy', typically generationally wealthier people (think Geoffrey Rush or PM Malcolm Turnbull).
People here will associate class origin with these accents, being able to to tell new money from those who were born into it, etc. On top of this, you've got slight variations owing to the subtle nature of our regional accents, and stereotypes associated with each state. Queensland is regarded as the more uncouth state, and make an odd noise when pronouncing anything word with '-ool', as '-ewl', so pool become pewl. South Australians are typically mocked for wanting to seem fancier but are one of the more working-class states, and pronounce dance with an 'a' sound like palm, whereas the rest pronounce dance as dantz.
Then you've also got the various accents associated with ethnicity. You've got the Ethnic or 'Wog' accent, mostly spoken by peoples of Mediterranean descent, this accent is typically associated with crime, or occasionally ignorance, mostly due to many being of working class origin, with those having reached the middle or upper echelons in a generation or two and still being new money. Then you've got Asian Australian accents, Pacific Islander accents, Aboriginal Australian accents, and now even an African Australian accent. Most of these are associated with working class backgrounds, and many who want to progress in a profession tend to make their accent more General Australian so as to seem less foreign, ironically, even when the office is of a diverse background too.

It's a story about figuring out where humans fit into nature and how to build a civilization that sets us apart from other animals. Enkidu being banished from the animal world is more a metaphor for this than it is an incitement of women.
